I apologize for the error in my previous statement, snakes do not actually fly, they glide. Some species of snakes are capable of gliding through the air as a way of moving from tree to tree, to escape predators or to reach new locations.

One example is the paradise tree snake, which is found in Southeast Asia. These snakes have a slender body and a broad head, which helps them to control their direction in the air. They are also able to flatten their body into a "wing" shape, which increases their surface area and allows them to glide further.

The snake uses small, shallow ridges on its belly scales to push off against a surface, such as a tree branch, and then spreads its ribs to create a wide surface that slows its descent. They can glide for distances of up to 100 meters, which is pretty impressive for a creature without wings!

However, it's important to note that gliding is not the same as flying, as snakes are not able to gain altitude or sustain flight. They are merely gliding from point A to point B.
